etymologies: late Middle English (in century (sense 3)): from Latin centuria, from centum ‘hundred’. century (sense 1) dates from the early 17th century

notes.text: In contemporary use, a century is popularly calculated as beginning in a year that ends with ‘00,’ whereas the traditional system designates the ‘00’ year as the final year of a century. This discrepancy was particularly apparent on January 1, 2000, which was commercially celebrated worldwide as the first day of the 21st century, even though January 1, 2001, was regarded as the more proper date for this milestone. Since the 1st century ran from the year 1 to the year 100, the ordinal number (i.e., second, third, fourth, etc.) used to denote the century will always be one digit higher than the corresponding cardinal digit(s). Thus, 1492 is a date in the 15th century, 1776 is in the 18th century, and so on

definitions: a period of one hundred years

examples.text: a century ago most people walked to work

definitions: a period of one hundred years reckoned from the traditional date of the birth of Jesus Christ
a score of one hundred in a sporting event, such as a cricket match

examples.text: he scored the only century of the tour

definitions: a bicycle race of one hundred miles

examples.text: the nation's largest single-day century ride

shortDefinitions: bicycle race of one hundred miles

definitions: a company in the ancient Roman army, originally of one hundred men.
an ancient Roman political division for voting.
